Situation A. Analyzing Game Moves—Using Equations

Amber and her classmates want to make a game called the Game of Zero for the school family game night.

Before making up the rules for the Game of Zero, students experiment with various game moves using the following board.
Write an equation that represents the total value of the chips on the board after the move.

Situation B. Amber’s Claim

Amber was working on the chip board and notices a pattern.

Amber’s Claim:

If you have the same number of black chips as red chips, the value is 0. For example, I can write this as +5 + –5 = 0.

  1. Do you agree with her reasoning? Explain.
  2. Is it possible to represent this on a number line? Explain.
  3. Describe three real life situations in which opposite quantities combine to make 0.

Situation C. Nadie Needs Help

Nadie’s Situation:

I was also analyzing moves on the chip board for the game. I have a chip board with 4 red chips. I need to subtract 2 black chips, but there are no black chips on the board. It is impossible to subtract 2 black chips. There are none on the board!

What can Nadie do to the chip board so that she can subtract 2 black chips? Explain your reasoning.

Situation D. The Game of Zero

After analyzing and representing moves on the chip board, Amber creates the Game of Zero.

Play the Game of Zero. Describe some winning strategies.

Equipment

  • black and red chips
  • chipboard
  • number cube
  • chipboard cards

Rules (play as teams or individuals)

  • A chipboard card is chosen randomly
  • All teams set-up a chipboard to match the chipboard card
  • Each team takes turns rolling a number cube. The team decides to add (red or black) or subtract (red or black) that number of chips from the board.
  • The team that gets their board down to zero first wins.
